I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) aims to achieve 
economic  growth,  reduce  poverty,  and  advance  from  its  least-developed-country  status  by 
2020. The National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES) was approved by the 
National Assembly of the Lao PDR in October 2003. The NGPES provides a broad strategic 
framework from which future growth and poverty reduction programs will be developed and 
implemented. The NGPES emphasizes the need for capacity building relating to public financial 
management (PFM) at all levels of public administration.1  
 
2.  The  Government  of  the  Lao  PDR  (the  Government)  has  requested  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide the proposed technical assistance (TA)2  to support the 
Lao PDR in improving its PFM. The proposed TA is included in ADB’s Lao PDR: Country 
Strategy  and  Program  2007–2011,  which  emphasizes  good  governance  as  one  of  three 
strategic pillars of development assistance to the country. A fact-finding mission was fielded to 
Vientiane from 30 April to 2 May 2007. The mission and representatives from the Government 
held  discussions  and  reached  an  understanding  on  the  objective,  scope,  cost,  and 
implementation  arrangements  of  the  TA.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The  2007  Public  Expenditure  Review  and  Integrated  Fiduciary  Assessment3  (PER), 
jointly undertaken by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, ADB, and the European 
Commission, noted that improving PFM and public expenditure policy will be critical to the key 
challenge of achieving the country’s socially inclusive development goals laid out in the sixth 
National Socio−Economic Development Plan and the NGPES. The Government has made 
progress in advancing the PFM  development agenda since 2002. In November 2005, the 
Government  approved  a  five-year  Public  Expenditure  Management  Strengthening  Program 
(PEMSP), which constitutes a cohesive framework addressing weaknesses in (i) fiscal planning 
and budget preparation; (ii) budget execution, accounting, and financial reporting; (iii) local 
government financial management; (iv) financial legislation and regulatory frameworks; and (v) 
technical  capacity.  Recognizing  that  building  sound  PFM  systems  requires  sustained 
development  over  the  medium-to-long  term,  external  partner  agencies  have  provided 
coordinated assistance to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) in the implementation of PEMSP.4 
 
4.  The  2007  PER  noted  that  PEMSP  pays  insufficient  attention  to  public  financial 
accountability and the critical role that an independent supreme audit institution could play in 
ensuring good governance. This conclusion is underscored by the Nam Theun 2 Revenue 
Management Arrangements (NT2 RMA), which require the State Audit Organization (SAO) to 
publish each year, starting from FY 2009, (i) an audit opinion of the statement of receipts and 
transfers of the NT2 revenue account, and (ii) an audit opinion covering the financial statements

5.  Accounting and Financial Reporting. ADB has provided technical assistance to the 
MOF for the development of (i) enhanced accounting regulations and procedures that are 
aligned with international good practice standards of reporting; and (ii) a government financial 
information system (GFIS) that is (a) capable of capturing revenue and recurrent expenditure 
data, (b) providing on-line access to budget targets/allocations and status of funds availability, 
(c) tracking accounts payable, and (d) producing related reports.6 ADB’s assistance led to 
implementation of the new accounting procedures and GFIS in 2005 across all 40 line ministries 
and government agencies and 17 provinces. This was the first time automation had been used 
on such a wide scale in Lao PDR’s PFM reform agenda. Line ministries and provincial offices 
have transitioned to the GFIS from manual books of accounts, but there is a need to deepen 
technical knowledge and extend the use of the GFIS. Given the demonstrated success in 
shifting to an automated system, MOF is now keen to start implementing the GFIS on a pilot 
basis in more progressive districts.  
 
6.  The Government does not as yet publish consolidated financial statements. A Financial 
Statement Committee was formed by the minister of finance in early 2007, comprising the 
various MOF departments, led by the Department of Accounting. The PEMSP aims to prepare, 
on a pilot basis, the consolidated annual statements for FY 2009. Although some advisory 
assistance was provided by ADB to MOF in 2006 with respect to preparing financial statements, 
continued assistance is required in light of the recently approved government financial statistics 
(GFS) compatible chart of accounts and the new Budget Law, passed by the National Assembly 
in December 2006. 
 
7.  Internal Audit. To enable sustained progress towards sound PFM, the currently limited 
inspection function within MOF’s Department of Inspection needs to be expanded into a broader 
internal audit and control function. Most inspection staff lack the needed technical background 
on accounting and auditing, and the very low English language proficiency of government staff 
makes it difficult for them to assimilate concepts of international good practice standards shared 
by external partner agencies. PEMSP plans to initiate publication of a summary report on the 
results  of  internal  audits  by  FY  2009.  Through  TA  4180  which  focused  on  enhancing 
government  accounting  regulations  and  procedures,  ADB  began  a  policy  dialogue  and 
increased awareness of the importance of undertaking reviews of internal control systems in 
government  agencies.  A  set  of  draft  internal  audit  regulations,  an  internal  audit  mandate, 
internal control policy statement, 5-year strategic action plan, code of ethics, internal auditing 
standards, and proposed organization structure and job descriptions were produced in 2006 for 
consideration by MOF. The Government’s commitment to PEMSP outcomes and the ambitious 
timelines will require further ADB support for implementing the internal audit function. 
 
8.  Independent  State  Audit  Function.  The  State  Audit  Organization  (SAO)  was 
established in 1998 through a decree by the prime minister, making it a unit of the Prime 
Minister’s  Office.  There  has  been  encouraging  progress  in  strengthening  the  organization 
following the appointment of new leadership in SAO in June 2006. The Audit Law was passed 
by  the  National  Assembly  in  July  2006  which  will  strengthen  the  effectiveness  and

9.  The  NT2  RMA  requires  that  SAO  undergo  audit  peer  review  by  an  International 
Association of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) member starting in 2006, in FY 2009 (or 
the first year of NT2 revenue flows), and every three years thereafter.7 The SAO has committed 
to implementing the first audit peer review in 2007. In light of the passing of the first Audit Law 
and the 2006 Budget Law, areas for ADB assistance will include revising the SAO’s 5-year 
strategic plan and audit manuals, continued training and capacity building, and assistance in 
strengthening areas of weaknesses that will be identified in the audit peer review.8     
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  contribute  to  improved  public  financial  accountability  and 
transparency  in  support  of  the  Government’s  development  and  poverty  reduction  policy 
objectives. The TA outcome will be (i) improved quality of reporting and internal control, and (ii) 
improved effective state audit oversight of public finances and expenditures. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Improving the Quality of Reporting and Internal Control. The first component of the 
TA will support the strengthening of the accounting and internal audit functions of MOF. The 
government accounting regulations and procedures will be revised to include the new features 
of the Budget Law and the new GFS-compatible chart of accounts. The GFIS and accounting 
regulations  and  procedures  will  be  introduced  and  implemented  in  the  38  districts  of  the 
provinces  of  Luang  Prabang,  Savannakhet,  and  Champassak,  and  Vientiane  Municipality. 
Capacity development workshops are to be held in all 40 line ministries/government agencies 
and 17 provincial offices, to deepen their technical capacity and provide continuous feedback for 
enhancing the system and regulations. The TA will also assist in developing a strategy for 
producing annual consolidated government financial statements, including a methodology and 
operating guidelines. Once approved by MOF, the TA will assist MOF in pilot testing preparation 
of the first set of consolidated financial statements. Computer equipment will be provided to the 
finance offices of the pilot districts, the provincial governor’s offices, the cabinet offices of the 
line ministries, government agencies and prime minister’s office, and the MOF Department of 
Accounting to support continued expansion of GFIS information technology (IT) infrastructure. 
 
12.  The TA will conduct training workshops for internal auditors on internal audit techniques, 
fundamentals of accounting and auditing, and the English language, and to create awareness of

the  internal  audit  functions.  It  will  provide  support  to  MOF  in  expanding  the  inspection 
department’s functions to include internal audits. The set of draft internal audit strategic plans, 
manuals,  policy  statements,  code  of  ethics,  and  proposed  organizational  structure  will  be 
revised in consideration of the 2006 Budget Law and GFS-compatible chart of accounts. Some 
computer and office equipment will be provided to augment inspection department capabilities 
and enable online access to PEMSP databases and the GFIS. 
 
13.  Improving Effective Independent State Audit. The second component of the TA is 
aimed at strengthening SAO capacity. SAO’s law committee will lead the preparation of the draft 
implementing decrees of the July 2007 Audit Law. The TA will assist SAO by providing advice 
on the drafting of implementing decrees, based on international good practice standards. It will 
also carry out nationwide workshops on the Audit Law and implementing decrees to better 
explain  their  application.  The  2007  INTOSAI  audit  peer  review  will  provide  the  baseline 
information on the capacity of SAO and will recommend areas for improvement. The TA will 
provide the necessary support to SAO while it undergoes its first-ever peer review and will 
develop training programs to assist SAO in (i) increasing its capacity, (ii) meeting international 
auditing standards, and (iii) ensuring its readiness for the succeeding INTOSAI reviews. The 5-
year strategic plan and set of five audit manuals will be revised to take into account the 2006 
Budget Law and the 2007 Audit Law. In consultation with stakeholders, new audit manuals for 
performance, procurement, and budget audits will be produced for implementation by SAO. 
Capacity building activities will include training on computer-aided audit procedures, practical 
application of the audit manuals, the English language, and fundamentals of public accounting 
and auditing. Training will be in the form of classroom and on-the-job training. The TA will 
support publication and distribution of the Audit Law and its implementing decrees, and provide 
needed equipment (e.g., computers, printers, and photocopy machines) as SAO expands its 
organization, work programs and linkages to the national databases. The TA will also support 
the participation of SAO in at least one international conference of state audit institutions to 
facilitate exchange of knowledge on international best practices. 
 
14.  All activities will be predicated on the requisite review and revision of existing systems, 
regulations,  and  processes in  light  of  the 2006  Budget Law,  the  GFS-compatible  chart  of 
accounts,  and  the  2007  Audit  Law  and  its  implementing  decrees.  Close  consultation  with 
stakeholders  such  as  the  different  ministries,  provincial  governments,  and  relevant  MOF 
departments will be held through participatory workshops, to build consensus and government 
ownership of the TA outputs. There will also be close coordination during TA implementation 
with external partner agencies involved in the broader PFM development agenda in Lao PDR. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $1,000,000. The Government has requested 
ADB finance $850,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the ADB’s TA 
funding  program.  The  Government  will  provide  in-kind  contribution  equivalent  to  $150,000 
through the provision of counterpart staff, office space and utilities, administrative services, and 
physical facilities. Appendix 2 gives the details of cost estimates and the financing plan.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Department of Accounting of MOF will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the first 
component of the TA. The Department of Inspection will be an implementing agency. The TA 
will use the existing PEMSP coordination mechanisms to facilitate review of implementation

5
progress of component 1 within the context of the PEMSP.9 SAO will be the EA for the second 
component. Progress reports to the auditor general will help ensure the timely implementation of 
component 2 of the TA. Each EA will assign a project director of senior stature, with two part-
time counterpart staff to assist in coordination.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 20 months from October 2007 to June 2009, and will 
require four international consultants over 26.5 person-months and three national consultants 
over  35  person–months,  working  intermittently.  There  will  be  two  teams  of  consultants  to 
implement the two components, with a team leader for each component reporting to ADB and 
their  respective  EAs.  Component  1  consultants  comprise  an  international  accounting  and 
internal  audit  specialist  (team  leader,  4  person-months),  international  accounting  training 
specialist (10 person-months), and an international audit training specialist (3 person months). 
Component 2 consultants comprise an international state audit specialist (team leader, 2.5 
person-months) and an international audit training specialist (7 person months). It is envisaged 
to  use  the  same  international  audit  training  specialist  for  components  1  and  2  to  ensure 
consistency of training programs, as internal and state audit functions are complementary in 
improving transparency and accountability. National consultants for component 1 comprise a 
national audit specialist and two national software development/training specialists, who will 
render 35 person–months of service. The consultant teams will produce various reports in both 
English and Lao, as outlined in their terms of reference, each of which will be discussed in 
tripartite meetings.  
 
18.  The consultants will be engaged through a firm following the quality- and cost-based 
selection process, and the simplified technical proposal will be used. The firm will provide the 
overall project management oversight over the two components of the TA. Both team leaders, 
through the firm, will report to ADB and the Government. There will be no reallocation of TA 
funds between TA components 1 and 2 without prior discussion and consent of the Government 
and ADB. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). All procurement under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement (2007, as amended from time to time) and 
the  international  training  specialists  will  assist  to  ensure  that  procurement  guidelines  are 
followed.  The  consultant  terms  of  reference are  in  Appendix  3.  Various  workshops  at  the 
central, provincial, and district offices will be held to encourage participatory discussions and to 
increase capacity of government staff. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Lao PDR for Improved Public Financial Management Systems, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
9  A PEMSP Program Steering Committee is chaired by the Vice Minister of Finance with representatives of the 
relevant MOF departments. It reviews progress and approves MOF departments’ work programs. A PEMSP 
Program Coordination Committee (chaired by the Minister of Finance) meets twice a year to update the PEMSP in 
line with progress in implementation, the Government’s policy directives and external funding support. Monitoring 
reports are produced on a semiannual basis.

or the External Relations Department, which will use the project financial management system), 
government agencies, and external funding agencies with interest in the PFM agenda in Lao 
PDR; and (ii) liaise closely with the project director of the Executing Agency (EA) of component 
1 (the MOF Department of Accounting). Specific tasks will include the following.

responsibility for ensuring timely introduction of the GFIS to the districts.

implementation plan for revising these procedures, for submission to the Minister

financial  statements  (on  a  pilot  basis),  given  the  concurrent  enhancement

include the strategy and implementation plan in the inception report. These will 
assist in identifying possible pilot areas for preparation of financial statements, 
based on a set of evaluation criteria agreed upon with MOF. 
(iv)  By the middle of TA implementation, and if resources permit, prepare (a) an 
assessment  of  changes  required  to  project  financial  management  systems
